Award.AwardTitle: Track 1: Increasing Diversity In Geosciences: The Urban Community College/Research University Partnership
Award.AbstractNarration: This program is addressing the necessity of attracting under-represented students to the geosciences in order to maintain a robust national workforce for the future. Through collaboration between Tarrant County College District (TCCD), a community college, and the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), a research university, 20 under-represented students are being recruited and prepared for successful transition from a community college to a research university in order to complete a B.S. degree in the Geosciences. The students are being placed in a mentoring program with faculty and peer mentors who meet with the students regularly to review progress. Students are expected to successfully take introductory courses in geology, chemistry, biology, math and physics during their first two years, and take part in a summer program that consists of a field trip experience at the end of their first year and research experience with UTA faculty at the end of their second year. A course in Professional Development and Critical Thinking is included as part of the research experience. The project is being overseen by a PI-chaired Executive Committee that consists of faculty mentors, the Co-PI's, and representatives from the professional geoscience community in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. Project evaluation is based on: 1) the ability to recruit at least 20 under-represented students, 2) the percentage retained while taking demanding courses, 3) the percentage at TCCD receiving an Associates of Science Degree, and 4) the percentage of students transferring to a research university in a geoscience B.S. program. If shown to be successful, this partnership can serve as a model for collaborating community colleges and research universities in other urban areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A workforce gap in the Geosciences between the supply of new university graduates and the job market demand has been recognized for a number of years, althought the supply and demand are more balanced in 2016 due to a temporary downsizing in the petroleum industry. 

One of the sources of new talent is minority students who are traditionally underrepresented in the Geosciences. The purpose of this NSF grant was to attract and retain underrepresented students from general education geoscience courses at both a urban community college (Tarrant County College District, TCCD), and a large urban research University (University of Texas at Arlington, UTA) that were located in the same county. We used a recruiting and retention model that included paid summer geological field trips offered by by the Community College, jobs as paid research assistants on faculty research projects at the Research University, tutoring in difficult classes, and financial aid for one major's course.

We recruited a cohort of approximately 10 students per year for three years for a total of 33 funded students. The results are:

27% of the students have graduated with a BS; all have professional jobs or are in Graduate School

42% of the students are still in school majoring in Geoscience

9% of the students switched to Engineering, another STEM major

6% switched to a non-STEM major

15% dropped out due to financial problems or family issues.

We were able to retain 69% of the students in Geoscience, but 78% remained in STEM fields. Financial issues were a significant problem for 13% of the students despite the modest help received from the NSF program.

The outcomes suggest that the model of paid field trips, paid research opportunities, modest financial aid and tutoring succeeds in attracting and retaining underrepresented students in the Geosciences. Community Colleges in urban settings and nearby Research Universities typically have large populations of underrepresented students in the Geosciences. Cooperation between those institutions to recruit, retain and train those underrepresented students in the Geosciences is a viable way to meet the future workforce needs for technical people.
